Description: Tom-tom, drum from from a hollowed wooden log, both ends are open and covered with skin and thongs of skin.
Curator's comments: In set with Af.2696. Register reads: "The Dor. Central Africa. From Petherick collection." See John Petherick, 'Egypt, the Soudan and Central Africa', 1861, p.401: (on the Dor) ‘In the centre of the village […] large tom-toms made of hollowed trunks of trees, well finished and strung with dressed buffalo hides, were used only on occasions of univeral rejoicing or to sound the alarm in time of war. The sound could be heard miles distant.’
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: John Petherick (sale 27.vi.1862, lot number not recorded)
